facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 275 of 1970 was filed from the Judgment and Order dated 6th June 1969 of the Mysore High Court at Bangalore in Writ Petition No. 3244 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 275 of 1970.  From the Judgment and Order dated the 6th June 1969 of the Mysore High Court at Bangalore, in Writ Petition No. 3244 of 1968

facts.text: The appellant was the owner of several acres of land at Bangalore.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the owner of several acres of land at Bangalore. The appellant developed an agricultural and horticultural Estate on that land.

facts.text: The appellant developed an agricultural and horticultural Estate on that land.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant developed an agricultural and horticultural Estate on that land. In the year 1967 there was a proposal to acquire the aforesaid property of the appellant.

facts.text: In the year 1967 there was a proposal to acquire the aforesaid property of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1967 there was a proposal to acquire the aforesaid property of the appellant. The land acquisition proceedings commenced.

facts.text: Land acquisition proceedings commenced.

anchor.surface_text: The land acquisition proceedings commenced. Possession of the property was taken in the month of April, 1967.

facts.text: Possession of the property was taken in the month of April, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Possession of the property was taken in the month of April, 1967. The notification under section 4 of the Land Acquisition Act was made in the month of May, 1967.

facts.text: Notification under section 4 of the Land Acquisition Act was made in the month of May, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The notification under section 4 of the Land Acquisition Act was made in the month of May, 1967. A declaration under section 6 of the Land Acquisition Act was made on 1 July, 1967.

facts.text: A declaration under section 6 of the Land Acquisition Act was made on 1 July, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: A declaration under section 6 of the Land Acquisition Act was made on 1 July, 1967. In the month of August, 1967 the appellant preferred claims.

facts.text: In the month of August, 1967 the appellant preferred claims for Rs. 18,83,650 as compensation.

anchor.surface_text: In the month of August, 1967 the appellant preferred claims. The claim for compensation preferred by the appellant was for Rs. 18,83,650.

facts.text: In the month of September, 1967 the Government paid a sum of 6,50,000/- as an installment.

anchor.surface_text: In the month of September, 1967 the Government paid a sum of 6,50,000/- as an installment. On 30 August, 1968 the Government wrote to the Divisional Commissioner

facts.text: On 30 August, 1968 the Government wrote to the Divisional Commissioner that the Government approved the award for the total of Rs. 6,57,870-15 in respect of lands measuring 86 acres 2 gunthas.

anchor.surface_text: On 30 August, 1968 the Government wrote to the Divisional Commissioner that the Government approved the award for the total of Rs. 6,57,870- 15 in respect of lands measuring 86 acres 2 gunthas.

facts.text: The appellant made an application under Article 226 of the Constitution in Writ Petition No. 3244 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant made an application under Article 226 of the Constitution inter alia for an order that the proviso to section 11 and section 15-A of the Mysore Land Acquisition Act

facts.text: The appellant sought order to strike down proviso to section 11 and section 15-A of the Mysore Land Acquisition Act 17 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: for an order that the proviso to section 11 and section 15-A of the Mysore Land Acquisition Act 17 of 1961 hereinafter referred to as the 1961 Act be struck down

facts.text: The appellant asked for writ of prohibition to the Deputy Commissioner to follow instructions in Government approval letter dated 30 August, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: and for further order that a writ of prohibition be issued to the Deputy Commissioner to follow the instructions given by the Government in their approval letter dated 30 August, 1968.

facts.text: The appellant asked for writ of mandamus directing the Land Acquisition Officer to maintain their own valuation in draft award dated 24 July, 1968 for Rs. 13,00,000/-

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also asked for a writ of mandamus directing the Land Acquisition Officer to maintain their own valuation expressed in the draft award dated 24 July, 1968 for the sum of Rs. 13,00,000/-

facts.text: The High Court held that the proviso to section 11 of the 1961 Act is valid.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the proviso to section 11 of the 1961 Act is valid. The reason given by the High Court is that the Deputy Commissioner is an agent

facts.text: Counsel for the appellant contended that the proviso to section 11 of the 1961 Act is unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant contended that the proviso to section 11 of the 1961 Act is unconstitutional. Section 11 of the 1961 Act deals with enquiry and award by Collector.

facts.text: The proviso to section 11 requires no award shall be made by the Deputy Commissioner without previous approval of the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to section 11 of the 1961 Act is that no such award shall be made by the Deputy Commissioner, without the previous approval of the State Government or such officer

facts.text: Section 15-A of the 1961 Act allows State Government to call for and examine records before award.

anchor.surface_text: Section 15-A of the 1961 states that the State Government may at any time before an award is made by the Deputy Commissioner under section 11 call for and examine the record

facts.text: The Supreme Court upheld the judgment of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, the judgment of the High Court is upheld. The appeal fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed.

holdings.text: The proviso to section 11 of the 1961 Act is valid

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the proviso to section 11 of the 1961 Act is valid. The reason given by the High Court is that the Deputy Commissioner is an agent

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deputy Commissioner acts as agent of government; award is offer of compensation on behalf of government

holdings.text: Section 15-A of the 1961 Act is in aid of the proviso to section 11 of the 1961 Act

anchor.surface_text: Section 15-A of the 1961 Act is in aid of the proviso to section 11 of the 1961 Act. Counsel for the appellant contended that the proviso to section 11 of the 1961 Act offended Article 31 2  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enables government to examine records for legality and propriety before award, supporting approval requirement

holdings.text: The contention that the proviso to section 11 of the 1961 Act offended Article 31(2) of the Constitution is utterly unsound

anchor.surface_text: The contention is utterly unsound. The Land Acquisition Act is a piece of legislation which provides for acquisition of property for public purpose by authority of law for an amount which may be determined in accordance with the principles specified in the Land Acquisition Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mysore Act amendment protected under Art 31(5); does not infringe central LA Act principles

holdings.text: An award made under section 11 of the 1961 Act is an offer of compensation

anchor.surface_text: An award made under section 11 of the 1961 Act is an offer of compensation. The Deputy Commissioner makes an offer. The Deputy Commissioner is an agent of the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso requires government approval as ultimate authority; award not final

holdings.text: The Deputy Commissioner is an agent of the Government

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner is an agent of the Government. The Government is the ultimate authority to approve the award. Therefore, the proviso enjoins that no award shall be made without the previous approval of the State Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acts in administrative capacity subject to government approval

holdings.text: The Deputy Commissioner is not acting in judicial or quasi-judicial capacity in making the award under section 11 of the 1961 Act

anchor.surface_text: It is wrong to suggest that any opinion of the Deputy Commissioner is being overreached by the State Government. The Deputy Commissioner is not acting in judicial or quasi- judicial capacity in making the award under section 11 of the 1961 Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Functions administratively as agent; no overreaching of judicial opinion

holdings.text: There were guidelines for the approval by the State Government under the proviso to section 11 of the 1961 Act; the submission that there were no guidelines is erroneous

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant submitted that there were no guidelines for the approval by the State Government under the proviso to section 11 of the 1961 Act. This is an erroneous submission.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Guided by ss 15, 23, 24; claimant remedies under s18; award not final (s26)

anchor.surface_text: The contention is utterly unsound. The Land Acquisition Act is a piece of legislation which provides for acquisition of property for public purpose by authority of law for an amount which may be determined in accordance with the principles specified in the Land Acquisition Act.
For these reasons, the judgment of the High Court is upheld. The appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner is an agent of the Government. The Government is the ultimate authority to approve the award. Therefore, the proviso enjoins that no award shall be made without the previous approval of the State Government.
For these reasons, the judgment of the High Court is upheld. The appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: It is wrong to suggest that any opinion of the Deputy Commissioner is being overreached by the State Government. The Deputy Commissioner is not acting in judicial or quasi- judicial capacity in making the award under section 11 of the 1961 Act.
For these reasons, the judgment of the High Court is upheld. The appeal fails and is dismissed.
